column61: and he was cured on the moment; but they told him that what the youngest son was bringing to him was poison apples
column62: that would bring him to his death.The King was very angry when he heard that
column63: and he went to his butler and said
column64: “Go out to the wood where my son is
column65: and shoot him
column66: and bring his heart here with you on the top of a gun and throw it to the dogs at the door; for I will never have him
column67: or anything belonging to him
column68: brought into the house
column69: ” he said.So the butler got the gun
column70: and went out to the wood; and when he saw the young man he was going to shoot him. “Why would you do that?” said he. So the butler told him all the father ordered him; and the young man said
column71: “Do not shoot me
column72: but save me. And this is what you will do. Go into the wood until you meet with a woodcock
column73: and shoot it
column74: and take the heart out of it

column76: ” he said

column1: It was a good while after that
column2: a beautiful young lady came to the King’s doorway in a coach and four
column3: and stopped at the door. “Send out my husband to me here
column4: ” she said. So the eldest son came out to her. “Was it you came to the garden for the apples?” says she. “It was
column5: ” says he. “What things did you take notice of in the cottage where I was?” says she.When the King heard all that
column6: he knew they had deceived him
column7: and that it was the youngest son who got the apples for his cure
column8: and he began to cry after him and to lament that he was not living to come back again. “Would you like to know he is living yet?” says the butler. “I would sooner hear it than any word ever I heard
column9: ” says the King.When the young lady heard that
column10: she bade the butler bring her to where he was
column11: and they went together to the wood
column12: and there they found him
column13: where he had been living on the fruits of trees through the most of the year. When the young lady saw him
column14: she said: “Was it you came to the house where I was in the garden?” “It was
column15: ” says he.There once lived in a small town in China a man named Hok Lee. He was a steady
column16: industrious man
column17: who not only worked hard at his trade
column18: but did all his own housework as well
column19: for he had no wife to do it for him. “What an excellent
column20: industrious man is this Hok Lee!” said his neighbors. “How hard he works! He never leaves his house to amuse himself or to take a holiday as others do!”But Hok Lee was by no means the virtuous person his neighbors thought him. True
column21: he worked hard enough by day
column22: but at night
column23: when all respectable folk were fast asleep
column24: he used to steal out and join a dangerous band of robbers
column25: who broke into rich people’s houses and carried off all they could lay hands on.“I will bind up my face
column26: ” said Hok Lee. “Doubtless the warmth will cure the swelling.” But no such thing. Next day it was worse
column27: and day by day it grew bigger and bigger till it was nearly as large as his head and became very painful.“This
column28: Hok Lee
column29: is no ordinary swelled face. I strongly suspect you have been doing some wrong deed which has called down the anger of the spirits on you. None of my drugs will avail to cure you
column30: but if you are willing to pay me handsomely I can tell you how you may be cured.”Then Hok Lee and the doctor began to bargain together
column31: and it was a long time before they could come to terms. However
column32: the doctor got the better of it in the end
column33: for he was determined not to part with his secret under a certain price
column34: and Hok Lee had no mind to carry his huge cheek about with him to the end of his days. So he was obliged to part with the greater portion of his ill-gotten gains.When the doctor had pocketed the money he told Hok Lee to go on the first night of the full moon to a certain wood and there to watch by a particular tree. After a time he would see the dwarfs and little sprites who live underground come out to dance. When they saw him they would be sure to make him dance too. “And mind you dance your very best
column35: ” added the doctor. “If you dance well and please them they will grant you a petition and you can then beg to be cured; but if you dance badly they will most likely do you some mischief out of spite.” With that he took leave and departed.

column1: Happily the first night of the full moon was near
column2: and at the proper time Hok Lee set out for the wood. With a little trouble he found the tree the doctor had described
column3: and feeling nervous he climbed up into it.He had hardly settled himself on a branch when he saw the little dwarfs assembling in the moonlight. They came from all sides
column4: till at length there appeared to be hundreds of them. They seemed in high glee and danced and skipped and capered about
column5: while Hok Lee grew so eager watching them that he crept farther and farther along his branch till at length it gave a loud crack. All the dwarfs stood still
column6: and Hok Lee felt as if his heart stood still also.In great terror Hok Lee proceeded to come down; but he was so nervous that he tripped near the ground and came rolling down in the most absurd manner. When he had picked himself up he came forward with a low bow
column7: and the dwarf who had first spoken and who appeared to be the leader said: “Now
column8: then
column9: who art thou and what brings thee here?”“It is well
column10: ” replied the dwarf. “We will see about that. First
column11: however

column13: perhaps we may be able to do something; but shouldst thou dance badly we shall assuredly punish thee
column14: so now take warning and dance away.”With that
column15: he and all the other dwarfs sat down in a large ring
column16: leaving Hok Lee to dance alone in the middle. He felt half-frightened to death
column17: and besides was a good deal shaken by his fall from the tree and did not feel at all inclined to dance. But the dwarfs were not to be trifled with.So in despair Hok Lee began. First he hopped on one foot and then on the other

column22: leaving Hok Lee to find his way home as best he might.Nor were his fears unfounded

column24: and he could hardly see out of his eyes. Hok Lee felt in despair
column25: and his neighbors jeered at him more than ever. The doctor
column26: too

Ere long the dwarfs came trooping out till all were assembled.“What dost thou want?” they asked; and Hok Lee proceeded to tell them of his fresh misfortunes and begged so hard to be allowed one more trial at dancing that the dwarfs consented
column30: for there is nothing they love so much as being amused.Now
column31: Hok Lee knew how much depended on his dancing well
column32: so he plucked up a good spirit and began
column33: first quite slowly and faster by degrees
column34: and he danced so well and gracefully
column35: and made such new and wonderful steps
column36: that the dwarfs were quite delighted with him.With these words he and the other dwarfs vanished
column37: and Hok Lee
column38: putting his hands to his face

column40: and he went to bed happy and resolved never to go out robbing again.

column1: Next day the whole town was full of the news of Hok’s sudden cure. His neighbors questioned him
column2: but could get nothing from him

column6: and Hok Lee told him of the dwarfs and their dances.The neighbor went off
column7: carefully obeyed Hok Lee’s directions
column8: and was duly cured by the dwarfs. Then another and another came to Hok Lee to beg his secret

column10: so that at length Hok Lee became a very wealthy man and ended his days in peace and prosperity.A poor Old Woman
column11: who lived with her one little granddaughter in a wood

column13: that asked her for the cane. She declined giving it to him

column15: and she was going to take the cane home and let her little granddaughter suck its sap.When the Old Woman reached her cabin she sat down by the door and wailed
column16: for she knew that she had no means of defending herself against the Boar. While she sat crying a vender of needles came along and asked her what was the matter. She told him
column17: but all that he could do for her was to give her a box of needles. The Old Woman stuck the needles thickly over the lower half of the door
column18: on its outer side
column19: and then went on crying.Just then a Man came along with a basket of crabs

column21: and stopped to inquire what was the matter. She told him
column22: but he said he knew no help for her

column24: behind her door

column26: who was coming along from the fields

column33: and then sat down to cry again.A courier returning on horseback from a neighboring town was the next to pass her door
column34: and he dismounted to inquire what troubled her. Having heard her tale
column35: he said he would leave his horse to stay with her
column36: and make the ox more contented. So she tied the horse to the foot of the bed
column37: and
column38: thinking how surely evil was coming upon her
column39: she burst out crying anew.A boy just then came along with a snapping turtle that he had caught and stopped to ask what had happened to her. On learning the cause of her weeping he said it was no use to contend against sprites
column40: but that he would give her his snapping turtle as a proof of his sympathy. She took the turtle
column41: tied it in front of her bedstead
column42: and continued to cry.Some men who were carrying millstones then came along
column43: inquired into her trouble

column45: which they rolled into her back yard. While they were doing this a Man went by carrying hoes and a pickaxe
column46: and he stopped and asked her why she was crying so hard. She told him her grief
column47: and he said he would gladly help her if he could
column48: but he was only a well digger and could do nothing for her except to dig a well. She pointed out a place in the backyard
column49: and he went to work and quickly dug a well.

column1: On his departure the old woman cried again
column2: until a Paper Seller came and inquired what was the matter. When she told him he gave her a large sheet of white paper
column3: as a token of pity
column4: and she laid it smoothly over the mouth of the well.At midnight the Boar came and threw himself against the door to break it in. The needles wounded him sorely
column5: so that when he had gained an entrance he was heated and thirsty
column6: and went to the water jar to drink.Then in a rage he approached the front of the bed; but the snapping turtle nipped his tail and made him retreat under the feet of the horse
column7: who kicked him over to the ox
column8: and the ox tossed him back to the horse. Thus beset
column9: he was glad to escape to the back yard to take a rest and to consider the situation.An old woman had five grown-up sons that looked just alike. The eldest could gulp up the ocean at a mouthful; the second was hard enough to nick steel; the third had extensible legs; the fourth was unaffected by fire; the fifth lived without breathing. They all concealed their peculiar traits
column10: and their neighbors did not know they were queer.The eldest supported the family by fishing
column11: going alone to the sea
column12: and bringing back loads of spoil. The neighbors often besought him to teach their sons how to fish
column13: and he at last let all their boys go with him
column14: one day
column15: to learn his art. On reaching the shore he sucked the sea into his mouth
column16: and sent the boys to the dry bottom to collect the fish. When he was tired of holding the water
column17: he beckoned to the boys to return
column18: but they were playing among strange objects and paid no heed to him. When he could contain the sea no longer
column19: he had to let it flow back into its former basin
column20: and all the boys were drowned.As he went homeward
column21: he passed the doom of the parents
column22: who inquired how many fish their sons had caught and how long they would be in coming back. He told them the facts
column23: but they would not excuse him. They dragged him before the magistrate to account for the loss of their children. He defended himself by saying he had not invited the boys to go with him
column24: and had consented to their going only when the parents had repeatedly urged him; that after the boys were on the ocean bed
column25: he had done his utmost to induce them to come ashore; that he had held the water as long as he could
column26: and had then put it in the sea basin solely because nothing else would contain it.He went alone and told his brothers of his doom
column27: and the second brother returned in his stead to the judge
column28: thanked him for having given him permission to perform a duty required by filial piety
column29: and said he was then ready to die.A second knife and a third of finer steel were brought and tried by headsmen who were accustomed to sever heads clean off at one stroke. Having spoiled their best blades without so much as scratching his neck
column30: they took him back to prison and informed the judge that the sentence could not be executed.When the old woman’s son heard this decision he said that he took leave of his mother supposing that his head was to be cut off
column31: and that if he was to be drowned he must go to her and make known his fate and get her blessing anew.Permission being given
column32: he went and told his brothers what had happened. The third brother took the place of the second and presented himself before the judge as the criminal that was to be sunk in the sea. He was carried far from shore and thrown overboard
column33: but he stretched his legs till his feet touched bottom
column34: and he stood with his head in the air. They hauled him aboard and took him farther from land
column35: but still his extensible legs supported him above the waters. Then they sailed to mid-ocean and cast him into its greatest depths
column36: but his legs still lengthened so that he was not drowned. They brought him back to the judge
column37: reported what had been done
column38: and said that some other method of destroying him must be followed.On hearing this the judge condemned him to death by being boiled in oil. While the caldron was being heated he begged and obtained permission to go and tell his mother of the way he had survived from the attempt to drown him
column39: and of the manner in which he was soon to be taken off.

column1: His brothers having heard the latest judgment
column2: the fourth one went to bear the penalty of the law and was lowered into the kettle of boiling oil. In this he disported himself as if in a tepid bath
column3: and he even asked his executioners to stir up the fire a little to increase the warmth. Finding that he could not be fried
column4: he was remanded to prison.At this the populace
column5: the bereaved parents
column6: and the magistrate joined in an effort to invent a sure method of putting him to death. Water
column7: fire
column8: and sword all having failed
column9: they finally fixed upon smothering him in a vast cream cake.As he was able to exist without air he rested peacefully till the next midnight
column10: and then safely crawled forth
column11: returned to his home
column12: and dwelt there happily for many years with his remarkable brothers.A long time ago
column13: at a temple called Morinji
column14: there was an old teakettle. One day
column15: when the priest of the temple was about to hang it over the hearth to boil the water for his tea
column16: to his amazement the kettle all of a sudden put forth the head and tail of a badger. What a wonderful kettle
column17: to come out all over fur!The priest
column18: thunderstruck
column19: called in the novices or assistants of the temple to see the sight; and while they were stupidly staring
column20: one suggesting one thing and another another
column21: the kettle
column22: jumping up into the air
column23: began flying about the room. More astonished than ever
column24: the priest and his pupils tried to pursue it; but no thief or cat was ever half so sharp as the wonderful badger kettle. At last
column25: however
column26: they managed to knock it down and secure it; and
column27: holding it in with their united efforts
column28: they forced it into a box
column29: intending to carry it off and throw it away in some distant place
column30: so that they might no more be plagued with the goblin.For this day their troubles were over
column31: but as luck would have it
column32: the tinker who was in the habit of working for the temple called in
column33: and the priest suddenly bethought him that it was a pity to throw the kettle away for nothing
column34: and that he might as well get a trifle for it
column35: no matter how small. So he brought out the kettle
column36: which had resumed its former shape and had got rid of its head and tail
column37: and showed it to the tinker. When the tinker saw the kettle
column38: he offered twenty copper coins for it
column39: and the priest was only too glad to close the bargain and be rid of his troublesome piece of furniture. And the tinker trudged off home with his pack and his new purchase.That night
column40: as he lay asleep
column41: he heard a strange noise near his pillow; so he peeped out from under the bedclothes and there he saw the kettle that he had bought in the temple covered with fur and walking about on four legs. The tinker started up in a fright to see what it could all mean
column42: when all of a sudden the kettle resumed its former shape. This happened over and over again
column43: until at last the tinker showed the teakettle to a friend of his
column44: who said
column45: “This is certainly an accomplished and lucky teakettle—you should take it about as a show
column46: with songs and accompaniments of musical instruments
column47: and make it dance and walk on the tight rope.”The tinker
column48: thinking this good advice
column49: made arrangements with a showman
column50: and set up an exhibition. The noise of the kettle’s performances soon spread abroad
column51: until even the princes of the land sent to order the tinker to come to them; and he grew rich beyond all expectations. Even the princesses
column52: too
column53: and the great ladies of the court
column54: took great delight in the dancing kettle
column55: so that no sooner had it shown its tricks in one place than it was time for them to keep some other engagement.Many hundred years ago there lived an honest old woodcutter and his wife. One fine morning the old man went off to the hills with his bill hook to gather a faggot of sticks
column56: while his wife went down to the river to wash the dirty clothes. When she came to the river
column57: she saw a peach floating down the stream; so she picked it up and carried it homeward with her
column58: thinking to give it to her husband to eat when he should come in. The old man soon came down from the hills
column59: and the good wife set the peach before him
column60: when
column61: just as she was inviting him to eat it
column62: the fruit split in two and a little baby was born into the world. So the old couple took the babe and brought it up as their own; and because it had been born in a peach
column63: they called it Momotaro
column64: or Little Peachhing!When they got to the ogres’ island
column65: the Pheasant flew over the castle gate and the Ape clambered over the castle wall
column66: while Little Peachling
column67: leading the Dog
column68: forced in the gate and got into the castle. Then they did battle with the ogres and put them to flight
column69: and took their King prisoner. So all the ogres did homage to Little Peachling
column70: and brought out the treasures which they had laid up. There were caps and coats that made their wearers invisible
column71: jewels which governed the ebb and the flow of the tide
column72: coral
column73: musk
column74: emeralds
column75: amber

column1: In the old days there lived two lizards

column5: by stretching his long neck

column13: ” he sang
column14: and the women sat so still

column25: and saying

column34: an’ dat why de Peafowl hav such a beautiful dress.Once upon a time there dwelt near a large wood a poor woodcutter with his wife and two children by his former marriage
column35: a little boy called Hansel and a girl named Grethel. He had little enough to break or bite
column36: and once
column37: when there was a great famine in the land
column38: he could not procure even his daily bread; and as he lay thinking in his bed one evening
column39: rolling about for trouble
column40: he sighed
column41: and said to his wife
column42: “What will become of us? How can we feed our children when we have no more than we can eat ourselves?”“Know
column43: then
column44: my husband
column45: ” answered she
column46: “we will lead them away quite early in the morning into the thickest part of the wood
column47: and there make them a fire
column48: and give them each a little piece of bread; then we will go to our work and leave them alone
column49: so they will not find the way home again and we shall be freed from them.” “No
column50: wife
column51: ” replied he
column52: “that I can never do; how can you bring your heart to leave my children all alone in the wood
column53: for the wild beasts will soon come and tear them to pieces?”“Oh
column54: you simpleton!” said she

column56: “Ah
column57: but I shall regret the poor children.”The two children
column58: however
column59: had not gone to sleep for very hunger
column60: and so they overheard what the stepmother said to their father. Grethel wept bitterly
column61: and said to Hansel
column62: “What will become of us?” “Be quiet
column63: Grethel
column64: ” said he; “do not cry
column65: I will soon help you.” And as soon as their parents had fallen asleep
column66: he got up
column67: put on his coat
column68: and

column71: and the white pebbles which lay before the door seemed like silver pieces
column72: they glittered so brightly. Hansel stooped down
column73: and put as many into his pocket as it would hold
column74: and then going back he said to Grethel
column75: “Be comforted
column76: dear sister
column77: and sleep in peace; God will not forsake us;” and so saying he went to bed again.The next morning
